citation_key_or_title: Xie/Huang et al. (2024) NeurIPS - Can Large Language Model Agents Simulate Human Trust Behaviors?
main_claim: LLM agents (GPT-4) can replicate human-like trust and reciprocity patterns including risk adaptation, prosocial preferences, and demographic biases
why_relevant: Primary replication target - direct LLM-LLM trust game with human baseline comparison and BDI reasoning framework
what_to_replicate: One-shot and repeated Trust Game with BDI prompting; demographic variation experiments; trust vs dictator game comparisons

citation_key_or_title: Akata et al. (2025) Nature Human Behaviour - Playing repeated games with large language models
game(s): Prisoner's Dilemma, Battle of the Sexes, Stag Hunt
main_claim: GPT-4 exhibits near-optimal but unforgiving strategies in iterated PD, struggles with coordination games, but improves dramatically with Social Chain-of-Thought prompting
why_relevant: Demonstrates strategic personality differences across models and critical role of prompting interventions (SCoT) for coordination and ToM
what_to_replicate: Repeated PD with memory; Social Chain-of-Thought prompting technique; coordination game dynamics

citation_key_or_title: Horton (2023) - Large Language Models as Simulated Economic Agents: What Can We Learn from Homo Silicus?
main_claim: LLMs trained on human text encode latent social information and can serve as implicit computational models of human economic behavior
why_relevant: Foundational framework establishing LLMs as Homo Silicus - provides theoretical justification and methodological grounding for using LLMs as economic agents
what_to_replicate: Persona endowment techniques; preference encoding methods; validation against human behavioral data

citation_key_or_title: Sreedhar et al. (2025) - Simulating Cooperative Prosocial Behavior with Multi-Agent LLMs
main_claim: Multi-agent LLM systems replicate human cooperation patterns across experimental treatments (priming/transparency/heterogeneity) and exhibit emergent behaviors like coordination and cheating
why_relevant: Demonstrates LLM-LLM cooperative dynamics in N-player games; validates treatment effects; shows emergent strategic behaviors
what_to_replicate: Public goods game with varying treatments; multi-agent coordination protocols; contribution tracking over rounds

citation_key_or_title: Wang et al. (2023) - Self-Consistency Improves Chain of Thought Reasoning in Language Models
main_claim: Sampling multiple reasoning paths and marginalizing via majority vote substantially improves LLM reasoning accuracy
why_relevant: Critical sampling technique for generating robust behavioral distributions from LLMs rather than single-shot outputs
what_to_replicate: Self-consistency sampling protocol; majority voting aggregation; temperature/sampling parameter effects

citation_key_or_title: Aher et al. (2023) ICML - Using Large Language Models to Simulate Multiple Humans and Replicate Human Subject Studies
game(s): Milgram obedience, Wisdom of crowds, Garden path sentences
main_claim: GPT-3/GPT-4 can replicate classic human experimental findings (65-75% obedience in Milgram) but exhibit hyper-accuracy and hyper-obedience artifacts
why_relevant: Establishes methodology for LLM human simulation; identifies key artifacts (over-accuracy/over-obedience); demonstrates persona variance techniques
what_to_replicate: Multi-persona sampling; artifact detection methods; validation protocols against human experimental benchmarks

citation_key_or_title: Agarwal et al. (2025) - Will Systems of LLM Agents Cooperate: An Investigation into a Social Dilemma
main_claim: Attitudinal conditioning ("aggressive" vs "cooperative" prompts) dramatically shifts equilibrium outcomes in multi-agent LLM systems
why_relevant: Direct LLM-LLM strategic interaction with prompt-based preference manipulation; shows plasticity of cooperative behavior
what_to_replicate: Iterated PD with attitudinal personas; equilibrium convergence tracking; prompt sensitivity analysis

citation_key_or_title: Choi et al. (2025) - Pay What LLM Wants: Can LLM Simulate Economics Experiment with 522 Real-human Persona?
main_claim: LLMs can capture group-level behavioral patterns when grounded in real human persona data, though individual predictions remain noisy
why_relevant: Demonstrates real persona grounding technique (vs fictional); compares prompting strategies (CoT/RAG/few-shot); validates group vs individual prediction accuracy
what_to_replicate: Real persona injection format; prompting method comparison; group-level aggregation validation

citation_key_or_title: Park et al. (2024) - Do Role-Playing Agents Practice What They Preach? Belief-Behavior Consistency in LLM-Based Simulations of Human Trust
main_claim: LLMs exhibit belief-behavior gaps where stated beliefs about trust don't always align with actual sending/returning behaviors
why_relevant: Trust-specific analysis of persona consistency; identifies when role-play breaks down; critical for validating simulation fidelity
what_to_replicate: Belief-behavior consistency measurement; trust-specific persona validation; gap detection methods

citation_key_or_title: Akata et al. (2025) IJCAI - Game Theory Meets Large Language Models: A Systematic Survey
game(s): Multiple (survey coverage: matrix games, auctions, mechanism design)
main_claim: Comprehensive taxonomy of LLM-game theory intersection identifies evaluation gaps, prompting effects, and emergent strategic behaviors across 140K+ game instances
why_relevant: Provides taxonomies and frontier summary; identifies methodological gaps; comprehensive literature positioning
what_to_replicate: Taxonomy of game types and LLM capabilities; evaluation framework categories; frontier identification

citation_key_or_title: Vezhnevets et al. (2023) - Concordia: Generative agent-based modeling with actions grounded in physical/social/digital space
main_claim: Concordia framework provides modular architecture for grounding multi-agent simulations with memory, planning, and action components
why_relevant: Architectural patterns for multi-agent systems; grounding mechanisms; memory/planning/action decomposition
what_to_replicate: Agent architecture schemas; grounding component design; multi-agent orchestration patterns

citation_key_or_title: Alekseenko et al. (2025) - Strategizing with AI: Insights from a Beauty Contest Experiment
main_claim: LLMs exhibit more sophisticated iterative reasoning (higher level-k) than humans in beauty contest games, converging faster to equilibrium
why_relevant: Tests iterative strategic reasoning depth; shows LLMs may exceed human sophistication in some strategic domains
what_to_replicate: Beauty contest game protocol; level-k reasoning measurement; convergence dynamics tracking

citation_key_or_title: Murashige & Ito (2025) - Simulating Human Decision-Making in Ultimatum Games using LLMs
main_claim: GPT agents replicate fairness preferences and algorithmic aversion effects, but miss anonymity impacts on behavior
why_relevant: Provides dictator game control baseline; tests fairness vs strategic trust; identifies anonymity comprehension gap
what_to_replicate: Ultimatum/Dictator game comparison protocol; anonymous condition implementation

citation_key_or_title: BIS/Bank of Canada (2025) - AI Agents for Cash Management in Payment Systems
main_claim: AI agents replicate prudential liquidity management but are vulnerable to herding and coordinated panic equilibria when exposed to peer behavior signals
why_relevant: Demonstrates systemic trust dynamics (coordination failure); relevant for future bank run extension; shows social trust vs dyadic trust
what_to_replicate: Bank run coordination game; information contagion protocols; systemic stability metrics

citation_key_or_title: Akata et al. (2025) IJCAI - Game Theory Meets Large Language Models (alternate version)
main_claim: Same as arxiv_2502.09053v2 - comprehensive survey of LLM-game theory with systematic taxonomy
why_relevant: Same as survey entry above - provides context and positioning
what_to_replicate: Same as survey - taxonomies and frameworks

citation_key_or_title: ACL 2025 Tutorial - LLM Guardrails and Agent Safety
main_claim: RLHF safety alignment may constrain economic strategic behavior; models may refuse "ruthless" or deceptive strategies needed for valid game simulations
why_relevant: Identifies RLHF tax on strategic behavior; suggests roleplay framing to access full behavioral range
what_to_replicate: Safety-economics tradeoff analysis; roleplay framing techniques to enable strategic behaviors

citation_key_or_title: Zhao et al. (2025) - LLM-Auction: Generative Auction towards LLM-Native Advertising
main_claim: LLMs can participate in complex allocation mechanisms, integrating auction logic with generation to optimize advertiser value and user experience
why_relevant: Adjacent - auction mechanisms rather than trust/cooperation; may inform future mechanism design extensions
what_to_replicate: Auction participation protocols; bidding strategy emergence

citation_key_or_title: GWU (2025) - FOMC In Silico: Multi-Agent System for Monetary Policy Decision Modeling
main_claim: Multi-agent LLMs can simulate complex institutional decision-making processes like Federal Reserve monetary policy committees
why_relevant: Adjacent - macroeconomic application; demonstrates LLM scalability to institutional contexts but not directly about trust
what_to_replicate: Multi-agent deliberation protocols; institutional role modeling

citation_key_or_title: Siren Attack Framework - Learning-Based Multi-Turn Attack for Simulating Real-World Human Jailbreak Behaviors
main_claim: LLMs can be manipulated into multi-turn deceptive strategies including financial fraud scenarios (Ponzi schemes)
why_relevant: Adjacent - fraud/deception scenarios; relevant for ""dark side"" safety analysis but not core trust research
what_to_replicate: Multi-turn deception protocols; fraud scenario construction
